@Ohh Zeek - Stars are different colors primarily due to both surface temperature and the Doppler Effect.  The surface temperature dictates what color the 'flame' of the star is with blue being the hottest and red being the coolest.  In addition, the Doppler Effect 'tints' objects (not just stars) blue or red depending on whether they are moving towards or away from us respectively.  Seeing as how we orbit the sun, this latter effect would not matter as much.  With red being the coolest star, we would most likely die due to being too cold rather than to radiation exposure.

I think this is their one video with a LOT of misconceptions. First of all, cells don't stop replicating when telomeres run out. Cancer does not "evade" cell death; in fact, it quickens it because of the rapid reproduction shortening its telomeres. If a tumor is benign but in an inoperable area sometimes doctors will leave it in knowing it will die if the cancer does not spread.

Well reasoned and entirely correct. Embryonic Stem Cells contain Telomerase, an enzyme which lengthens telomeres, and it is from these 'immortal' cells your whole body is grown. Throughout your life, you will keep a steady stock of stem cells, which will replace the cells lost due to damage or ageing.
The idea that your own body has a timeclock, in the form of telomeres, which will kill you when time runs out, is wrong.

Most of your cells aren't actually dividing.  The cells in say, your liver, are basically done.  The only time they need to divide is when one of their neighbors dies, which is pretty rare.  Cells that need to divide all the time, like bone marrow, have machinery called telomerases that keep the telomeres the same length.  So, generally speaking, the 50 divisions will last you your entire life - its usually something else that would get you first...

The top and bottom lids of each eye have puncta that lead to the lacrimal ducts which drain tears that are produced to lubricate the eye.
